G.L. c. 212, \u00a74.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over the subject matter of this action pursuant to **G.L. c. 212, §4**, which confers jurisdiction upon the Superior Court over civil actions for damages exceeding $25,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a78.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester County pursuant to **G.L. c. 223, §8**, as the events giving rise to this action occurred in Worcester, and the property at issue is located there.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).proposition: Defendant owed a duty of reasonable care to maintain her premises, including the abutting sidewalk under her control, in a reasonably safe condition to prevent foreseeable harm to lawful visitors, invitees, and others lawfully upon the property.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).support_reasoning: The provided excerpt is only a short concurring passage about classifications of entrants (trespasser/licensee/invitee) and does not discuss any duty to maintain premises or abutting sidewalks, nor the scope of duty to lawful visitors or invitees. While the full Mounsey opinion does expand landowner duties beyond the invitee/licensee distinction, this specific text does not itself establish the proposition regarding a duty to maintain premises and abutting sidewalks in a reasonably safe condition. Thus, based solely on the quoted text, the case does not clearly support the claimed proposition.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973).relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors.

Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..proposition: Defendant breached that duty by failing to take reasonable measures to remove or treat the hazardous ice and by failing to warn foreseeable visitors of the danger presented.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that property owners owe lawful visitors a duty of reasonable care with respect to hazards from snow and ice, which includes making reasonable efforts to remove or treat dangerous accumulations and to protect visitors from such dangers. Although it does not list the plaintiff’s specific allegations in those exact words, the court adopts a general premises-liability standard that encompasses failure to remove, treat, or warn of hazardous ice as a potential breach of duty.
Papadopoulos v. Target Corp., 457 Mass..relevant_excerpt: We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to “act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.” … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.proposition: Defendant’s conduct fell below the standard of care required of reasonable property owners under the circumstances.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the standard of care for landowners and holds that a landowner owes a duty to maintain property in a reasonably safe condition, including remedying even open and obvious dangers when harm is reasonably foreseeable. The court explains that setting up and maintaining the trampoline immediately adjacent to the shallow pool, knowing people would jump from one to the other, could constitute a breach of that duty and should have been submitted to the jury under a proper instruction. Thus, the case supports the proposition that defendants’ conduct may fall below the standard of care required of reasonable property owners under these circumstances.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148 (201.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises. … This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … Here, Jose set up a trampoline immediately adjacent to a two-foot-deep pool…for the very purpose of enabling people to jump from the trampoline into the pool. … On these facts, a jury were entitled to conclude that the defendants owed a duty of care — specifically a duty to remedy — despite the open and obvious nature of the danger.”

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).proposition: Defendant’s breach of duty was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses causation only at a high level, noting that causation is ordinarily a jury issue, but the court’s actual holding is limited to recognizing that Kask owed a duty of reasonable care and that summary judgment on negligence was improper. It does not hold that any breach by Kask was the direct and proximate cause of Officer Jupin’s injuries; instead, it remands for a jury to determine breach and causation. Thus, the case does not support a proposition that defendant’s breach was the direct and proximate cause of plaintiff’s injuries.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … We generally consider the latter three questions … to be the special province of the jury. … We therefore reverse summary judgment on the negligence claim and leave to a jury the determination whether Kask exercised reasonable care.”

Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.,.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.,.proposition: Plaintiff’s fall and resulting injuries were foreseeable and preventable had Defendant acted with ordinary care.
Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The quoted concurrence states that the facts would not warrant a finding that the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence. That directly rejects foreseeability of the plaintiff’s injuries, which is the opposite of the claimed proposition that the fall and injuries were foreseeable and preventable with ordinary care. Thus, this case does not support the proposition; it undercuts it.
Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: "I concur in the view that '[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff's injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.' Ante at 640-641."

Thompson v. Forest Hills Gardens Co., 47.raw_text: Thompson v. Forest Hills Gardens Co., 478 Mass. 1001 (2017)
Thompson v. Forest Hills Gardens Co., 47.proposition: Defendant had actual and constructive notice of the dangerous icy condition, having been notified by tenants with photographs prior to Plaintiff’s accident, but failed to act.

Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.raw_text: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Auth., 363 Mass. 165 (1973)
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the sidewalk and her disregard for tenant complaints constitute actionable negligence under Massachusetts law.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.case_name: Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.support_reasoning: The case involves a slip-and-fall on a stairway in a subway station, not a landlord–tenant sidewalk case. The Supreme Judicial Court ultimately holds that the evidence was insufficient to show the defendant’s negligence because there was no proof the foreign substance had been present long enough to be discovered and removed; it orders judgment for the defendant. While the opinion recites the general duty of one in control of premises to use due care to keep them reasonably safe, it does not hold that failure to maintain a sidewalk plus disregarding tenant complaints is actionable negligence, and in fact is a defense-friendly insufficiency-of-proof decision.
Oliveri v. Massachusetts Bay Transp. Aut.relevant_excerpt: “1. The obligation of one who controls business premises is to use due care to keep the premises provided for the use of its patrons in a reasonably safe condition, or at least to warn them of any dangers that might arise from such use, which are not likely to be known to them, and of which the defendant knows or ought to know… In summary, recovery has been denied to the plaintiff in the great majority of cases where he has attempted to establish the time element by circumstantial evidence…”

Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.raw_text: Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mass. 837 (1987)
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the sidewalk and her disregard for tenant complaints constitute actionable negligence under Massachusetts law.
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co. concerns a gasoline station’s duty (or lack of duty) to warn customers of the obvious risk of injury from other vehicles at a self‑service station. It does not address landlord-tenant duties, sidewalk maintenance, or landlord liability for ignoring tenant complaints. In fact, the court finds no duty to warn of an obvious danger, which is the opposite of using the case to establish actionable negligence for failing to maintain premises and respond to complaints.
Young v. Atlantic Richfield Co., 400 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “In my view, the risk of injury to a customer from the negligent operation of another vehicle on the premises of a self-service station is inherent and obvious. There is no duty to warn of such a danger.”

Foley v. Boston Housing Auth., 400 Mass..raw_text: Foley v. Boston Housing Auth., 400 Mass. 821 (1987)
Foley v. Boston Housing Auth., 400 Mass..proposition: As a direct and proximate result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff suffered serious pain and suffering, medical expenses, and lost wages.
Foley v. Boston Housing Auth., 400 Mass..case_name: Massachusetts Coalition for the Homeless v. Secretary of Human Services
Foley v. Boston Housing Auth., 400 Mass..support_reasoning: The case is an administrative/public benefits dispute about AFDC standards and homelessness, not a tort or personal injury action. The opinion does not address negligence, proximate cause, or personal damages such as pain and suffering, medical expenses, or lost wages. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that, as a direct and proximate result of a defendant’s negligence, a plaintiff suffered such damages.
Foley v. Boston Housing Auth., 400 Mass..relevant_excerpt: We conclude that (1) the Legislature has established the AFDC standard of need in recent budgets and that the department acting under G. L. c. 18, § 2 (B) (g), has not; (2) the department nevertheless has an annual duty under G. L. c. 18, § 2 (B) (g), to review its budgets of assistance; (3) the department has an obligation to advise the Legislature whenever the department concludes the AFDC funds are not sufficient to permit it to provide the level of financial aid described in G. L. c. 118, § 2; (4) the department is directed by G. L. c. 118, § 2, to provide aid sufficient to permit AFDC recipients to live in homes of their own; and (5) there should be further proceedings concerning the declaratory or injunctive relief which may be appropriate as to homeless AFDC families.

Ward v. Merchants Mut. Ins. Co., 418 Mas.raw_text: Ward v. Merchants Mut. Ins. Co., 418 Mass. 486 (1994)
Ward v. Merchants Mut. Ins. Co., 418 Mas.proposition: Plaintiff continues to experience ongoing discomfort and disruption to her normal activities as a result of Defendant’s negligence.
Ward v. Merchants Mut. Ins. Co., 418 Mas.case_name: Ulwick v. Massachusetts Insurers Insolvency Fund
Ward v. Merchants Mut. Ins. Co., 418 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether a personal injury claim against an insolvent insurer is a “covered claim” under the Massachusetts Insurers Insolvency Fund statute. It does not address the plaintiff’s physical condition, ongoing discomfort, or disruption to normal activities, nor does it make any factual or legal finding about continuing injuries caused by the defendant’s negligence. Therefore, it does not support the cited proposition about ongoing discomfort and disruption of normal activities.
Ward v. Merchants Mut. Ins. Co., 418 Mas.relevant_excerpt: On September 26, 1986, a motor vehicle which was owned by the defendant Gulla, operated by the defendant Salvatore, and insured by American Mutual, struck a motorcycle that Ulwick was operating without fault in the course of his duties as a city of Melrose police officer. The American Mutual policy provided liability coverage of $100,000 per person for personal injuries. Since the accident, Melrose has paid Ulwick's medical bills, an amount exceeding $100,000, as required by G.L.c. 41, § 100 (1992 ed.). Melrose has also paid more than $100,000 to Ulwick for lost wages pursuant to G.L.c. 41, § 111F (1992 ed.).

G.L. c. 231, \u00a76B.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover all compensable damages proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence, including interest and costs as permitted by **G.L. c. 231, §6B**.
